qas.question: What has successfully dealt with ozone depletion?

answers.text: global regulation based on the Montreal Protocol

qas.question: What did the Kyoto Protocol try to address?
Whose goals often still oppose the IPCC?
Kyoto Protocol dealt with which depletion?
What process do both science and governments follow?
What goals do both science and government have in common?
Who do states and governments often work in lockstep with?
What will be assured because of the political response to the linear model?

context: The IPCC process on climate change and its efficiency and success has been compared with dealings with other environmental challenges (compare <b3_0>Ozone depletion<b3_0/> and global warming). In case of the Ozone depletion <a0_2><b5_0>global regulation<b5_0/> based on <a0_0>the <a0_1>Montreal Protocol<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> has been successful, in case of <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>Climate Change<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, the Kyoto Protocol failed. The Ozone case was used to assess the efficiency of the <b4_0>IPCC process.<b4_0/> The lockstep situation of <b6_0>the IPCC<b6_0/> is having built a broad science consensus while <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>states and governments<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> still follow different, if not opposing goals. The underlying linear model of <b7_0>policy-making<b7_0/> of more knowledge we have, the better the political response will be is being doubted.
